SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: Statistical Consulting Support from the SCS

SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to Probability for Data Analytics

summary_comment: Dr. Craigmile is widely regarded as an exceptional statistics professor, known for his engaging and enthusiastic lectures, which are both entertaining and informative. Despite his hyperactive demeanor, his clear notes and thorough explanations make the material accessible. While the workload is demanding, particularly with challenging homework and exams, students find his dedication and responsiveness invaluable, making the effort worthwhile.

Ratings.comment: best statistics professor ever

Dr. Craigmile's lectures are great. He's a bit hyperactive, which makes the class way more interesting. His notes are pretty clear and going to class helps tremendously. Be prepared for him to go SUPER fast, though. He says to students, "I write my exams so I wouldn't get a perfect score." You have to work REALLY hard, but it's worth it!
Pretty nice guy has really cool Irish accent. Go to class pay attention and do the HW and you'll do really well in this class.
watch out for very hard homework and even harder exams
Very good teacher. Very enthusiastic and dedicated. Also, very helpful. He gives very clear examples and explanations.

The class was a lot of work, but *great* instructor. Very organized, *excellent* notes, responsive to questions. Lectures were engaging and entertaining. Be warned that he wanders (physically) a lot; sit in the back if you want to keep him in view! Cool Scottish accent, too.

SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: The Statistical Analysis of Time Series

summary_comment: Daryl is a knowledgeable professor with engaging, high-quality lectures that are particularly beneficial for students who are already familiar with the subject matter. However, his teaching style can be inconsistent, with some students finding his explanations clear and others feeling that he does not cover difficult topics thoroughly enough. Tests are generally fair but can be challenging, especially for those who struggle to manage time effectively during exams.

Ratings.comment: I've taken AP Statistics before so I was already familiar with 90% of the course materials. His lectures are probably the best ones I've had and I was able to understand and practice without having to look up or go through textbooks for additional guidance. His tests are manageable if you fully understand the course materials. He has humor as well!

I took his async class, he was an alright professor who provided a ton of material for help. If you do the homework and tophat you will understand the material. Daryl can be kinda boring and did not lecture the more difficult material as well. He is an alright professor, not bad, not great.

The class itself isn't bad; watch the lectures and fill in the blank slides with him and you'll be okay. The tests are fair contentwise, but they're very long and hard to finish on time unless you know what you're doing. His lectures are actually solid, but he spends a lot of time on easier material, and not enough on hard material.

Reading other reviews I guess that the online version of the class was not good but taking it in person this semester I really enjoyed it, Daryl is nice and funny and the in person classes had a lot of interaction with students despite being a class of 200 people (only 50-70) actually showing up usually. Study for tests and pay attention.

I had him when classes came back to in-person. He's an ok lecturer, but the class(which format he didn't write) feels really surface level and a waste of time. His tests are his own and he usually tested what he pointed to with TopHat questions. He did a good job trying to prepare us, there weren't any surprises and he let us use formula sheets.

This guy was bad. All of the classes were lectures recorded some year/s ago and were difficult to understand on top of taking up more time than one would be in class. Homework assignments were nothing like the tests. Tests are graded harshly and have more content than you can finish in the given time. He refuses to curve when averages are failing.

For an async class he provided a LOT of resources for studying/doing hws. Honestly an OK lecturer; Lectures are a hit or miss, either over-explaining or not explaining enough. Hws are disconnected from lectures (hes aware of this) and have limited attempts. Thankfully hes pretty responsive to emails. Hes not THAT bad but definitely not the best.

Professor is a super nice guy, but with all due respect, cannot teach to save his life. His lectures are a couple of years old, filled with mistakes. I recall one time he was explaining something and was like "This is because .... it just is what it is". The class is hard, just be prepared to study the practice exams a lot.
Online and had over 600 students so very independent class. Not helpful and not flexible. Does not reply to emails quickly and the overall course is not formatted well.

Lectures/lecture notes are outdated & not the best, but the book, office hours, and community make this class very manageable. He gives sample midterms/finals and keys that had (very) similar problems to the actual exams. He can be blunt with students but he ended up curving our class generously and really wasn't as bad as many made him out to be.

Uses pre-recorded lectures he recorded a couple of years ago. They're not very useful. Assigns homework and quizzes on WebAssign. Exams look nothing like homework and quizzes. Get ready to do a lot of self-teaching if you get this man as your prof.

Daryl seems like a very nice and likable guy, though he uses lectures that are several years old and have multiple mistakes and audio issues. Overall hes very approachable and kind, but his tests are very hard

Daryl is a horrid professor. His lectures, for some reason, are three years old and far longer than they need to be. Daryl does not care about your grade and makes that clear in his weekly videos where he talks about how the class is designed to have incredibly difficult midterms and a final being held up by homework and quizzes. Take 2470 at CSCC

Asynchronous class, but a really reasonable amount of work for a stats class. I had multiple weeks where I didn't have to do anything but study for exams. Daryl's office hours are awesome, but he can come off a little blunt/rude over email so would avoid that. If you do the work and stick to a schedule, it's not too bad at all.

If you watch the lectures and keep up with the work it is not bad. The quizes always have extra credit, and not a ton of homework. The lecture videos are also short and straight to the point. First midterm was easy, second was a lot harder but do-able.

Has zero lectures anduses recordings that are at least 2 years old. The recordings don't reflect the material in the homework. The homework doesn't reflect the material in the midterms/final. To his credit, he does hold weekly homework/exam study sessions that he attends Don't risk taking unless you are already very familiar with statistics.

Prepare to put your whole time in the semester to study for this class. The test questions are way harder than any practice problems given. His lectures are easy to understand but there are way more than if it is given in a in-person class. There are a lot of terms in the textbook that are different from his lecture beware. Class average not good.

Terrible class, but especially online. Lecture videos are several years old and the audio on them is terrible and they are longer than an actual in person class. This class is being offered in person next semester. So try that. It's probably done better in person than online.

He does not lecture, just posts videos that are several semesters old, full of mistakes, and have horrible audio quality. Lectures such that even if you are familiar with the content you will be lost. Exams are so far beyond the level of difficulty of the quizzes and the homework. Truly could not put in less effort, avoid if you want a good grade.

Daryl has good intentions but is unsuited for the online class. He doesn't do anything except post videos that are two years old. The lectures are nowhere close to the difficulty of the exams and they themselves are your entire grade. He seems nice, unfortunately you don't get too much interaction with him outside of office hours

Took him over summer. I hated his online structure. HW and Quizzes are useless. His exams were hard. Dont expect a curve because he curved only 1% plus. Try to study a lot and catch up if you want a good grade. At least he cares about his students like a lot of office hours, answering discussion board. Use those if you need help.

Probably fine in-person. Horrible online. Recorded lectures are not good, and exam problems were entirely different from anything practiced in lectures or on homework. I'd probably give him the benefit of the doubt for in-person stats, but online he seemed to put in the bare minimal amount of effort for the class.

Daryl wasn't the worst professor and clearly knew how to teach beginners but I hated how this class was structured online. Prerecorded lectures each week that are way longer than spending time in an actual class learning. Ch 6 was the only unit that was taught differently than what was on exams. He cares but puts no effort into teaching.

I took this class online over the summer, and I had a pretty good experience with it. I went to office hours once and posted on the discussion boards a few times when I was confused, and he responded quickly and explained things rather well. The structure of this class is lecture and homework heavy, but the exams are what to look out for.

Took him online and it wasn't my favorite. Daryl clearly shows that he's passionate about teaching stats to students and while you could get what he is trying to communicate, his video lectures do a poor job solidifying concepts. Also the exams were your only grade so goof one and your hopes of getting a good grade are done

I had an online class with all material recorded, and optional homework sessions but they were at a time that I had other classes, and his office hours were 8 am on a friday... I wish this class just had a dedicated time you could schedule. He had 500 students and no live lectures, of course this class sucks. He cares but doesn't put in the effort.

Dont take him for this class if you can. If you have to avoid the online section. The prerecorded lectures were terrible and barely explained anything well. Just some concepts with like only one example and thats it. No actual help from him other than what was minimally required from him. Exams were difficult but made worse online.

I'm sure these previous reviews regarding Daryl over the past few years are true to their core. However, with online learning Daryl is rather lazy. His lectures have no organized format and he provides no extra help other than what is needed. I took him for Stat 3470 SU21, and by far he is the worst professor I have ever had. I would not recommend.

Lectures can be long but are good resources for exams. The assignments in this course are fair as long as you practice the material and study for exams. It is easy to fall behind and get lost if you aren't on top of actually working through the homeworks and quizzes. Overall, Daryl was a good lecturer and provided a lot of notes and other material.

Great human being. Is a bit paranoid about tests and talking about them after you have taken them, but I think he may of had a bunch of students cheat in semesters prior so I get it. The subject is not easy. Id put it in hardest 10% of classes Ive taken as a CSE majorup there with 2421. 3470 as a whole likely sucks, Daryl is a good option for it.

Very few men on this planet carry an appreciation for statistics comparable to that of Daryl's. Lectures have their limits when some difficult topics are covered, but Daryl is more than willing to help. Homework is reasonable in frequency, but don't do it last minute. Exams are reasonable and study guides are plentiful. Start HW early.

You need to study hard for this class the exams are not hard as long as you do review the material and do the practice questions. I personally do not find the webassign hw useful. The class is set up to be very flexible, you only need to complete weekly hw and tophat and discussions are due before exams. Do not wait till last minute.

Daryl is a really nice guy, the class itself is just so hard for people who are thrown into it. Do the WebAssigns without googling them, make a review sheet before exams, and go to office hours and you will most definitely end up with a solid grade. He made the exams super hard though, but it weeds out those who studied and didn't.

Daryl is a very a tough grader and does not update grades throughout the semester so you go into each midterm not knowing your grade. Also said during one of his review sessions that he makes multiple choice hard on purpose to trick students. Would never take him again and would recommend not taking him.

Very frustrating teacher with unclear lectures. I took pass fail because of his lack information and it turns out there will be a large curve announced way past the pass/fail date. Would have nice for him to have said it earlier so students could make an educated decision. AVOID at all costs.

Disconnected lectures and exams. Video lectures don't explain concepts. Not enough practice problems. Doesn't use Carmen correctly. Syllabus doesn't have information needed (when assignments are due/exam dates).

His lectures are awful. The length is way longer than the time you would be in class if it were taught in person and there aren't enough examples to teach you the concepts in order to do well on the TopHat questions and homework. He also requires an absurd amount of work and overexplaining on his exams in order to even receive a B. Overall bad prof

I had him pre-Covid, and is by far one of my favorite instructors. He was enthusiastic when lecturing, he added humor to the top hat questions which were for participation, but I think you only had to get %50 of them correct to get the full points. He taught stats in high school, so he knows how to teach to beginners. Tests are pretty difficult

Absolute nightmare. Imagine putting on tophat questions you haven't even covered before and doesn't even explain how to do it. It's been like this the entire semester and I'm honestly just fed up. No effort done to transition things online at all.

Daryl's teaching for 3470 ranges from adequate to excellent. The class seems fair, and there are plenty of opportunities for practicing concepts, including homework problems, sample midterms, TopHat problems, textbook problems, and additional review problems. There's also a bunch of tutoring available. Only problem: strict grading on midterms.

Does close to no actual teaching. His lectures lack concrete examples and he rarely ever explains the variables he uses. Exams poorly reflect content from homework and quizzes. Terrible professor, perhaps it is because the class is online this semester, but he has not adjusted at all.
Prerecorded lectures that are below average at best. Barely gives examples and doesn't provide reasoning. Get ready to learn it on your own.

If you're taking this class in the future please avoid the professor, if you care about your gpa. He doesn't teach a lot in the class, only gives pre-recorded lectures and that's basically it. You'll be on your own reading the book and studying the material by yourself. You won't learn from him, you just have to learn the material yourself.

My best bet is that he's probably better off teaching in person, as shown by the good reviews at the very beginning, but isn't the best with the online version of this course. His prerecorded lecture videos basically require you to know the material already as he doesn't always explain clear enough. Enough practice problems are also not given.

In my opinion, I think he's very hard and doesn't give enough examples during his pre-recorded videos. Also, he assign TopHat problems with no explanation of why that's the correct/incorrect answer. In the discussion post, he doesn't respond very thoroughly to the student question. His exam reviews won't help you enough to be ready for the exam.

Daryl did not do enough to help us learn Stats online. While he had good intentions, all he did was post prerecorded lecture videos, which were pedantic, and had us copy the slides as we watched. Additionally, there were no practice problems other than Tophat and they were barely helpful without step by step explanations.

Daryl is prompt in answering questions, but never posts grades. We only have the midterm on Carmen. His exams are fair--very similar to the reviews and practice exams he posts (with answer keys!). However, the lectures are not representative at all of the class's difficulty. You really have to work to learn this material, but it's not impossible.

Daryl has not taught once during this semester. He just has pre-recorded videos. Not very helpful. The assignments, like TOPHAT and WebAssign, resemble the course content very little. No effort on his part to adapt to online learning.

Class is really struggling to adapt to online learning. Around an hour of online pre-recorded lectures each week. Concepts are explained, w/ little to no reinforcement/practice. There's an online textbook that is somewhat helpful. Hopefully this class gets fixed next semester. No grades put in until the first midterm... by then its too late to drop

This class is an absolute train wreck online. The other reviews are completely correct in that Daryl provides horrible lectures that leave you more confused than when you started. This leads to having to learn everything by yourself, as his lectures don't provide any relevant examples. This is the worst experience I've had learning at OSU so far

I was doing poorly on the tophats despite watching all the videos, and I thought that it was my own problem for not understanding well enough. Then I saw here that it's not just me with the same problem. His lecture examples are really different from homework and tophat questions, and I feel really lost in this class after watching all the videos.

Daryl is straight up not a good professor. His lectures provide no applicable examples for problems you see on his TopHat questions and homework assignments making them very hard without consulting the textbook and working through the assignments for hours. AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

Daryl has a self described love for Stats and for teaching Stats to students, but that couldnt be more wrong. His lectures provide no examples that accurately represent what youll see on his TopHat questions, Homework assignments, or tests. Get prepared to teach yourself everything about Stats because Daryls lectures are borderline useless.

I loved taking Daryl for statistics because he was so passionate about the material. He always tried his best to make lectures interesting, whether by some sort of story or through an in-class demostration. He makes his own notes for the class to fill in as he's teaching and has you talk about in-class problems with the people sitting next to you.

Really nice guy and great lectures that explain the concepts well. Gives lots of help, including a cheat sheet on the exam, but doesn't always give the most helpful hints when emailing him about HW. All the test question were examples from class or from the review sheet, and all the HW questions could be answered easily with the lecture slides.

I cannot stress this enough, DO WHATEVER IT TAKES TO ADJUST YOUR SCHEDULE TO HAVE DARYL. If you are confused about anything go to his office hours and ask about it. He's so good at giving help and breaking down hard concepts. He gives exam review questions and solutions and the actual exams are very similarly worded and structured.

Daryl was one of the better professors I've had. Very clear about what he expects on exams and about what you need to know. Tries very hard to answer questions well and is eager to help people that approach him. He uploads his notes to Carmen and lets you bring in a front-and-back formula sheet on exams.

summary_comment: The professor is widely regarded as ineffective in her teaching methods, with students finding her notes unhelpful and lacking in study aids like practice problems. The online version of the course relies heavily on poorly assembled PowerPoint presentations, making it difficult to learn the material without additional resources.

Ratings.comment: She is horrible at teaching, notes aren't very helpful, no study guide or practice problems are given prior to a midterm except practice exams.
Online Stats 2480, only way to learn was through lazily assembled powerpoints. Just take the in person version and save yourself the headache.

summary_comment: The professor is noted for delivering dense lectures that make it challenging to grasp concepts, and her asynchronous teaching method lacks interactive elements like live Q&A sessions, which hinders understanding. Students find her assessments difficult due to significant discrepancies between practice exams and actual exams, and she does not curve grades, leading to low average scores despite many performing well on practice materials.

Ratings.comment: I was required to take this course for my major, but I strongly dislike asynchronous courses so this was not fun for me. Also, she would cram so much information into one lecture so it was difficult to finish learning a topic, but then the next lecture was about to happen.

She gives practice exams w/ multiple-choice and a couple extended responses, w/ 70 min to take them. The actual exams have a different format with no multiple choice in a 60 min timeframe. I get all the homework questions right on my first try & do well on the practice, yet somehow get 50%. The average is 50%, too. Yet, she doesn't curve.

This was an asynchronous class w/ prerecorded lectures & no mandatory zooms. The topics were hard to understand b/c I wasn't able to ask questions while learning. She's horrible at explaining topics & definitions, her lectures are entirely example problems, she uses numbers w/o explaining where she got them, and doesn't write out all her work.

summary_comment: Professor Chang is known for clear and organized lectures with comprehensive notes available online, making the class manageable with adequate preparation. However, the class is challenging, particularly with tough exams that often test material from homework assignments, leading to significant grade drops for mistakes. While some students find him patient and easy to follow, others struggle with the slow pace and unorganized structure of the course.

Ratings.comment: I cant recall much of Prof. Changs class. I think I was doing okay until the final, which was pretty tough. Changs lectures are ok, he talks really slow so I recommend 2x speed. He made sure to cover the concepts that were important in detail.

Lectures weren't great and could be hard to understand. Grading is very hard. Practice tests were provided and maybe half followed. I emailed once about clarification on emails he sent out, and he sent the emails to me again.

Might be the hardest class I've ever taken. The material itself isn't too bad but each homework assignment took many hours and browsing the textbook to understand how to solve the questions. Exams typically only have 4 questions so if you mess up one your grade drops substantially. On the bright side Professor Chang writes great notes.
This professor is actually garbage. DO NOT TAKE. Incredibly unorganized and makes non-difficult concepts difficult. Inable to explain 1+1 to a Phd student.

Professor Chang is definitely underrated on rmp: his lectures are clear and pretty straight forward, and class notes are all available on Carmen. If you prepare well on the materials and problems he emphasized in lecture, get an A would not be difficult.

I took his STAT4202 class last semester and got an A quite easily. He could explain every points clearly and makes hard chapters easily understood. Exams are not hard since most questions are from homework and sample practices. As long as you go to most of the lectures, you can get at least A-. I will definitely recommend people to take this class.

I was in Professor Lo-Bin Chang's 4202 class last semester. He is a very patient Professor who not only talk very clear during class, but also provide lecture notes, which is good for us to study after class. His exam is not hard at all, if you pay time to study. Some exam questions are directly pulled from homework.

Lo-Bin is a solid professor because he teaches the required info for course in an organized way. He posts lecture notes online. My only complaint is the lack of effort on the HW grading. He and the TAs consistently grade the easiest question on the homework, meaning hardly any feedback on your homework (but solutions are provided online after).

The amount of study required to do well in his class far exceeds any reasonable measure. Our study group at times put in 20-30 hours a week, attended office hours, and stayed after class to ask questions. The tests were still exceedingly difficult. TA's were inconsistent in the difficulty of their quizzes, and HW solutions were full of errors.

Avoid at all costs. Professor Chang does not teach the material well, in part due to the litany of mistakes he makes while lecturing. His exams are not at all reflective of the material learned in class, and he intentionally places trick questions in order to confuse you. The average on the final was a 49. What's the common denominator? Him.

Lo Bin was by far the worst professor I have had at the two universities I have attended, and I have had some pretty bad ones. He takes the material he poorly taught and takes them a step further on exams, so even if you understand the concepts, they are very hard. The average on our final was 49. Absolutely terrible, avoid him at all costs.

Lo-Bin is by far the worst professor I've ever had at the two universities I've attended. Every week he assigns homework and posts solutions online that are filled with mistakes. He then tells us to study those homework solutions to prepare for tests and quizzes. In my SEI I strongly recommended immediate termination and I hope they take my advice.

Lo-Bin was the worst professor I have had so far. 90% of your grade are exams, which are quite difficult (average on the final was a 49%). He used Canvas to do a normal curve on the midterms which was pretty unfair to the people who actually did well on them. Furthermore, his exams would test you on weird questions that had subtle tricks to them.

Teacher is the absolute worst I've ever had. Really hard to understand and terrible at explaining things. His TA's were even worse. Always assigned heavy homework and HW solutions had large amount of miscalculations/errors/and lack of explanation. Often used tools and tricks outside of the scope of the class to solve. Don't ever take this teacher.

His lectures are very unclear. It is difficult to understand his accent. His exams are very tough, and he gives problems that we did not talk about in class. Even the textbook doesn't talk about them. There is no curve an the end. Avoid him.
Lectures were boring and sometimes hard to understand. The homework quizzes were pretty tough. Midterms and final were passable, especially after the curve.

summary_comment: Prof. Kurtek is highly regarded for his effective teaching and clarity in lectures, often compared favorably to Sal Khan. Students find his explanations thorough and his willingness to help through office hours and emails commendable. While homework can be challenging and time-consuming, exams are generally fair and closely aligned with lecture content, offering opportunities like extra credit and free participation points.

Ratings.comment: Prof. Kurtek is a really good lecturer. His voice reminds me of Sal from Khan Academy. There is weekly homework that can be tough if you arent caught up with the latest coding functions taught. Exams were essentially a more heavily weighted homework with no time limit, just submit before the deadline. We also had a bigger term project due later.

Very solid professor for 3201. Lectures are engaging and clear. The exams are basically based on the problems he did in lectures, so do the problems again before exams. The homeworks are somehow difficult and lengthy, be sure to work with others. There is also a individual project that requires R Studio. Overall a very informative course.

Hands down one of the best professors I've had, if not the best. He explains everything clearly and is more than happy to answer any questions you have, and is very patient while doing so. His office hours are super helpful, and he always answers emails. Make sure you go to class though! 10/10 would recommend :)

He's an excellent professor who reiterates important ideas and makes sure that the class understands the concept. The class itself is easy, but could be difficult depending on understanding of previous material.
He's a good lecturer and if you don't go to class, don't expect to do well. Homework problems are relevant to exams. He is open to questions and emails and wants to see you learn.
Tests aren't easy, but they are fair. Weekly homework's aren't bad. He seems eager to teach and really wants the students to understand.

Kurtek is the best math professor at Ohio State. His exams are clear cut and follow the notespractice exams almost exactly. There's extra credit on all of the exams as well as free participation points for showing up to the stats recitation. You need the textbook for homework. Would definitely recommend!

Coming from calc, this stats class was refreshingly simple. took AP stats in HS which helped, but overall the only work he expects you to do is HW due every other week. He allows cheat sheets on exams, and his lectures are filled with examples, which is essential for learning stats. Never went to office hours, but he seems very willing to help

Anyone who gave this man below a 5 needs to reassess how they defined professors.  He finds real-life applications and examples in class that really encourage you to pay attention.  He is up front about what you are required to know, and helps as much as he can to make sure you know it. Best professor I've so far at OSU.

Dr. Kurtek is one of the best professors I've ever had. He was very encouraging yet not overbearing. He was willing to answer any question, and the homeworksexams were very straightforward. He genuinely wants to see his students do well in the course and makes the material applicable and interesting.

Awesome Professor, had a really cool accent, but was very easy to understand. He wanted everyone to get an A and really tried hard to make sure you knew what to do. Extended office hours to fit your schedule. Study guides identical to exam with different numbers.

He really wants students to do well and will extend office hours to fit your schedule. The homework was very easy and simple and the tests were almost identical to the study guides. It is easy to get a B with almost no effort and an A with some.

SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: Introduction to R for Data Science

summary_comment: Elly is highly regarded for her clarity and friendliness, making her one of the best math professors according to many students. However, her lectures can be vague and unorganized, leading to confusion and difficulty, particularly for those new to statistics. Despite the challenges, her supportiveness and leniency on exams are appreciated, though the workload and exam difficulty can be substantial.

Ratings.comment: Weekly assignments are not difficult if you watch her lecture videos carefully and she could always give help
The notes are unorganized. The exam is hard
Lots of work for a 2 credit course. However, you can really learn things! Elly is extremely approachable and friendly. She explains things clear and are always willing to help.
She was the best math professor I have ever had. The class is tough, especially for someone who hasn't studied Stats before, but she made it doable.

Elly was friendly enough, but her lectures were vague, uninteresting, and confusing. Her slides were always riddled with mistakes, so I started to question everything I copied down. Very inaccessible, with office hours only one day a week early in the morning. Get ready to really read the textbook and visit the MSLC to understand the material.

It looks like she is always thinking about other stuff when she is teaching. The notes are not clear and have many typos. We even don't understand what she wants to express. Exams are also hard. Many students dropped because they do no understand her teaching. She cannot give us a big picture of the class and only cares some tedious details of math

Elly is one of the greatest stats professors that I've had at Ohio State. Her lectures are super clear - and she makes statistics fun! Her tests were challenging in content, but she is a very lenient grader. Elly genuinely cares about her students. Her assignments are helpful. I would highly recommend taking a class with her.

I started off very interested in the subject, but my interest quickly waned. The first test was fairly hard, but the next test was difficult beyond all belief or comprehension. Nothing on the test was related to any concepts covered in any but the most subtle ways. The test period was the longest hour I have spent in Ohio.  Lectures unclear.
Lectures were not very well organized and often had errors.  Exams were more  a test of mechanics than theory.  Not helpful in office hours.

Dr. Kaizar is the best! Probably the best professor I've had in graduate school. Her online videos were funny and relevant. She was very quick to answer my questions and never made a student feel bad for not understanding something. Her tests were long but she curved them and was very fair. Absolutely loved her and would take her again!

Elly was knowledgeable and cared about student success.  She did some cool activities that showed how some sampling methods worked in the real world. Tests were quite challenging, not necessarily because of content but because of the way ?s were worded. Even though knowing SAS isn't a prereq, it would make your life a lot easier if you did.
Dr. Kaizar was always open to answering questions during class and to going back to explain a point that we didn't quite get.  I hope I have another class with her.

Professor Kaizar really knows the stuff she is teaching, and she is a very helpful (and delightful) person. The test tends to be on the harder side, but hard work pays off. One of the best classes I've had.
Very detailed teaching. Assigns a TON of home work problems, but very concerned about her students.

summary_comment: The professor is not considered effective by students, who found the lectures unhelpful and the teaching style confusing. Office hours were unproductive, and there was a lack of support materials for test preparation. However, the class content is relatively standardized, and consistent study can lead to success.

Ratings.comment: Not a good professor. Didn't really teach the class and wasn't helpful in office hours. Most of it was learning on your own.

He's a very smart person but he just cannot explain how to do any of the stuff in this class well. He jumps all over in lectures, and writes/talks fast. He is not helpful at all when it comes to test-prep as he does not post midterm reviews or practice questions nor does he indicate what the questions on the exam will be like. Would not recommend.

I had some internet issues for the first midterm and they were very helpful. This class is pretty standardized so as long as you listen to lecture and practice for it like any other math class you should be fine. I have to say that the test are pretty standard and do look through the practice problems they give you for midterm.

summary_comment: Professor Chkrebtii is highly regarded for her effective teaching and supportive approach, with students praising her clarity, accessibility, and willingness to help. Her lectures can be challenging at times but are generally well-organized and she offers generous grade adjustments. Students consistently highlight her kindness and dedication to their success.

Ratings.comment: Nice professor and teaches the material well. She can be very easily accessed outside of class and is good at explaining there too. She wants you to succeed in the course so she is super helpful, and there is some grade adjustment at the end to help.

She was on maternity leave halfway through the semester (just before in-person classes were canceled), but she did a really good job teaching the material and offered help whenever she can. Content can be easy or hard depending on how you did on the previous stat courses. Overall, she's a kind and caring professor!

Professor Chkrebtii is great and is my favorite professor in the Statistics department. This was the first semester the class was offered so they were very lenient on grading. Professor Chkrebtii was very caring, explained concepts very well, and had a great and consistent notation system.

I have never done as well in a class in my entire college career. Chkrebtii is literally the best professor I have had so far on main campus. She is very logical and mathematical in how she thinks, and I can tell she's gotten a lot better at teaching with her mind, reading old reviews. Just know your basic calculus and algebra.

Dr. Chkrebtii was extremely kind and helpful, and she knew the material very well. However, I didnt always leave class understanding the material or the work we did in the examples. Overall though, she was always willing to help in office hours and graded easily.

Dr. Chkrebtii is a great choice for STAT 3201. The class is simple: 6 homeworks, 3 exams, and a group project. The exams are straightforward; the averages are high 80's, if they are below that she will curve the grade. You do need to study though. Her lectures are sometimes confusing, but she cares about her students and makes the exams reasonable.
Oksana is an amazing professor! Very clear, organized and inspirational. Would definitely recommend!

Very organized and clear. Exams are easy (averages around 90s/high 80s). Not a lot of homework (6 total the whole semester). Often makes minor but obvious mistakes during lecture but an overall great professor!
Oksana is a great professor. Her lectures (and handwriting!) are clear and enjoyable. She is kind, understanding, and knowledgeable. I look forward to taking her class again next semester.
She has no self-confidence and you will not satisfy with her lectures which are full of mistakes and unclear explanation therefore just read the book!

She is new at teaching and it's obvious: little class control, lacks confidence and clarity. She is nice and she tries her best  but spends too long on concepts yet doesn't explain them clearly. During the semester, 2 students in the class keep asking lots of questions (some of them were too irrelevant) and one student who  corrected  nearly everything she did. This was a little bit annoying.

She is not there for you certainly. I could get higher grade with half effort spent for that class. You can take her class if you want to do all hws, projects, midterms etc.  but at the end you are gonna take probably B and learn class material from the book.
Note to myself: do not take a class from inexperienced professors

summary_comment: Professor Lovekar is known for his clear teaching style and willingness to help students, making his classes accessible despite the challenging homework. Students appreciate his fairness in exams and the potential to boost grades through a relatively easy final project. However, some find his use of R confusing and his pronunciation difficult to follow, which can hinder understanding.

Ratings.comment: Class was three times a week and not recorded, so it's pretty important you show up. The homework was hard but not impossible, & the tests were very fair. He's willing to answer pretty much any question if you go up to him after class or in office hours. The 'final' project is relatively easy and a great grade booster.

I even cannot understand why using R. He makes the whole class like a CSE course. And in fact, his pronunciation is bad. The zoom recording cannot translate his speaking into correct words. Homework is never covered in class. Never take his course again.

Professor Lovekar enjoys teaching stats and was very easy to understand. I recommend him for anyone taking stats 3201. His exams were very fair, however the homeworks were a little challenging, but if you stay up with lectures in this class then you will be fine.

summary_comment: Dr. Peruggia is a knowledgeable instructor who effectively explains complex statistical theory, though his lectures can be challenging and disorganized. Students appreciate his detailed explanations and thorough coverage of the material, but also find his exams demanding and the class structure sometimes confusing. Overall, while his teaching is highly regarded, students should be prepared for a rigorous and self-directed learning experience.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Peruggia was a great instructor this past semester for Stat 4301! The course content is rather difficult for an undergrad course since it is statistical theory, but he is able to cohesively explain the concepts well. I liked the system of quizzes as they provided good practice for the exams. Difficult exams but the course was curved in the end.

The lecture note is not useful and hard to recognize what he writes. He doesn't give any sample practices before the exam review. only gives the range of sections. The tests were hard, the exam questions were related, and if you didn't figure out the first one, the rest of the questions could not solve.

The slides are disorganized and hard to read his handwriting. I took the first in person class after Covid and he probably had too high expectation on students. The exams are heavy with two midterms and one final, each with hard prove with few numbers and given little partial credits. He has few examples on slides. Consider not taking his class.

Yes, he has an accent and sometimes it was hard to make out what he was saying, but it seemed to me that the real problem is that Professor Peruggia failed to show that he was very interested in teaching.His priority was going through the required material on time but not necessarily explaining it.
His class is really disorganized. his italian accent could drive people crazy.
Mario is a great teacher. He explains things in good detail, and is relatively funny, too. His practice midterms are a pretty close to his actual midterms.

Fun teacher and very clear, though he has a thick Spanish accent.  He likes cats a lot.  Easy to follow along in class, almost the same thing every day.  If you follow along with notes, you will be fine.
Peruggia is a fantastic instructor.  He really knows his stuff, and gives a great lecture.  Do not expect to be spoon-fed.  He expects you to work as hard as he does.

summary_comment: Professor Linder teaches Stats 2480 with high-quality instruction, focusing on exam reviews that closely mirror the actual test content. His classes appear straightforward and supportive, with clear expectations for success, making the course accessible and less demanding.

Ratings.comment: I took Linder's Stats 2480 class online. If you just do his review packets before every midterm and understand you will do well in the class. The exams are the same as his reviews. Seems like a very nice guy who cares about his students and not a very hard class.

summary_comment: This professor is widely regarded as ineffective in teaching, particularly in providing practical examples and support during office hours. Students find her lectures heavy on theory and lacking in application, often requiring additional resources like YouTube lectures to understand the material. Despite some positive feedback about her care and understanding, many students struggle with unclear communication, disorganization, and delayed grading.

Ratings.comment: DO NOT take this class with this professor. She can't teach. She doesn't give examples of how to do the problems she gives in the exams.

For what it's worth, the lectures are okay-ish, but they're not the best as it focuses too heavy on theory versus application. I often had to rely on lectures found on YouTube from the same class. Exams are definitely fair, so watching the lectures is a must. Although there are 200 people to a section, I do wish midterm grades would come in faster.

Professor does not show up to her scheduled office hours, tests are not undergraduate level she specifically says, on week 10 of a 14-week semester, and still don't have any grades. Who knows if I have an A+ or a F!
Good luck getting her to respond... 

I guess I'm just paying to be able to say I'm in Statistics class...
doesnt respond to anyones emails. doesnt give out practice exams.

For 3470, she seemed to really care about her subject material and her students, but was not great at conveying information in a meaningful way. The voice issues were a serious problem to the class, and the lectures were not very helpful. The high ratings on this page are almost certainly smurf accounts, no way around it. Hard class, but doable.

I took online summer Stats 3470 (not 3201) with Professor Cleymaet--her first time teaching it. It was disorganized and the lectures were not always engaging or clear. Her getting covid did not help. Nonetheless, the class was manageable. Homework was straightforward and 30% of the grade. We had 48 hours to do all three exams and could use notes.

The other reviews earlier don't match up to how professor Cleymaet is currently. I've received multiple extensions to homework and a lot of slack from the professor. During her lectures she sticks to the material that will be given on tests and homework so that students will be prepared and know exactly what to do for every question.

This class was substantially better than I expected when I took it online over the summer. Olivia was a great instructor (although her vocal injury and COVID-19 infection were disruptive to the course), extremely understanding, knowledgeable, & caring. If I had taken this course during the year w/ a different instructor, it would have been bad.

Actually terrible. I took AP Stats in high school and passed the exam, but she takes stuff and makes it unnecessarily difficult. Terrible at offering clarification, often giving students attitude. She curves inconsistently, is inaccessible and would not offer additional practice when requested. Crazy and simply weird. Never again

absolute garbage. shes terrible. does not know how to speak clearly and literally sounds like the dumbest professor on the planet. I cannot emphasize this enough DO NOT TAKE HER CLASS. she will make you want to rip your hair out.

She is the worst professor I have ever had in my entire college life. Mumbles and impossible to understand. Breeze through the content just by reading herself and doesn't care if students follow up or not. It is supposed to be an introduction class for stat but made it a total disaster. Just never ever try to be in her class.

Beware if this is your first Stats course. Finished with an A after the curve, but only after an ungodly amount of time in office hours, reading the textbook. Maybe it was her first time teaching, but I was literally lost on day 1 thanks to her very hard-to-follow lectures.

Honestly, stay away from this professor with everything in your power. If you do not have a great grasp of statistics concepts before stepping foot in the door on day 1, you will be completely lost - if you do have a great grasp, prepare to be frustrated beyond belief as she talks in circles and overcomplicates lessons. Impossible to understand.

summary_comment: This professor consistently receives high praise for his teaching quality, earning a perfect 5/5 rating from students. His detailed feedback and accessibility, especially in an online setting, are highly valued. While his lectures are challenging and theoretically oriented, they are also deeply rewarding for those prepared to engage with advanced material and motivated by thorough explanations.

Ratings.comment: 5/5, both difficulty and helpfulness.
He's a tough grader but dont take me wrong, you make A LOT out of his careful feedback. If you just want a high score, maybe hes not for you.
Although the course is online due to the epidemic, he provides very detailed and helpful discussion threads on weekly and he is very accessible. 5/5.
Not quite an in-class person. But he is amazing in explaining advanced theorems and motivating students. miss the classroom time with him during this period.

He is very very theoretically oriented, I have to say, even for a math major like myself. HUGE amount of math. However, his style is trying to motivate by using examples. If you have a strong theoretical background and prepared for the hard work ahead, attending his lectures will be rewarding.

summary_comment: The professor moves at a slow pace but thoroughly covers concepts and is willing to help, offering ample practice opportunities and fair tests. However, her lectures lack interest, and some students found her unhelpful and confusing, with poor note-taking practices and a lack of clear explanations. Others, though, highly praise her as the best professor they have encountered.

Ratings.comment: Class moved at a very slow pace, but overall thoroughly teaches the concepts and is very willing to help. She provides ample opportunities for practice, and her tests are fair. Lectures aren't the most interesting, but sweet lady.

Among the worst professors I've had. Seems to answer most students' questions with some variation of 'I don't know.' Bad at explaining things. Most lecture notes are just her writing stuff (not very legibly) on the projector in class, and these notes aren't uploaded to carmen so you can't review the class notes afterward.  Not recommended at all.

Wasn't a fan. Said "um" in every single sentence. So hard to pay attention. I heard good things about her going in but couldn't have been more disappointed in the actual class. Looking back, I essentially learned nothing. Attempted to rely on the poorly-written textbook. Would NOT recommend taking a class with her.
Best prof ever!

Arguably, the worst professor I've had at OSU. It's one thing for a professor to struggle teaching material, but she didn't even understand the material. Not a day went by that students weren't correcting her mistakes during lecture.

summary_comment: Professor Erin is perceived as knowledgeable and caring but struggles with effective teaching methods, leading to confusing lectures and mediocre exams. While some students find her approach challenging and unengaging, others appreciate her availability, clear notes, and willingness to help, noting it is possible to achieve high grades with effort. Overall, opinions are mixed, with some recommending against the class due to its difficulty and others praising her supportiveness.

Ratings.comment: Buckle up for an hour of boring lecture. Don't take the class. Knowledge after class zero and grades bad. I advise you not to take statistics with her, she brings more confusion.
She is one of the nicest and smartest teachers on campus but I think she doesn't know how to really teach the class and exams are mediocre.
If you want an hour confusion she is the right teacher for you.
There are way better teachers.

I cannot imagine taking this class with another instructor. Stats 135, as a typical GEC class, is both incredibly dull and full of busy work. The difference between Erin and other instructors is that she seems to care about what she is teaching, is crystal clear in lectures, and wants her students to do well.

Great Professor i've had for math! There is no reason for anyone to fail this class or even get a D.  She puts the notes online, alows u to use a page of notes on the exam, & is willing to meet outside of class if needed. This is a good class to take if u have other classes that are difficult to help balance the course load. I ended up with a A

I agree with everything that the previous poster wrote.  If you take the time to do the homework assignments and go to class, you can easily walk a way with an A or A- in this class.  Just make sure you bring good notes with you when taking the exams and read the problems carefully.  The level of math isn't that tough, and I normally suck at math.

She is a really good professor. She puts the notes online for those who miss class, however I don't rec skipping b/c there are assignments that are given in Lecture that are worth points. She's young(26-29) so I'm guessing thats why she is so understanding & wants U to do well. Class average ended up being a B but its not hard to get an A if U try.

summary_comment: Matthew is an average professor with mixed reviews; his lectures are not mandatory but can be beneficial as he provides thorough coverage of material, albeit sometimes quickly. He is considered engaging and funny, though his pacing can make note-taking challenging. His exams are known to be difficult, and while his teaching style has improved, some find his approach to be condescending.

Ratings.comment: Matthew is the median of all professors. He doesn't really care if you show up to lecture but he also isn't that great of a lecturer. He sometimes treats people like they are idiots for not understanding a concept but he does go over it again. Midterms were standardized and he wrote generally the toughest questions.

Good option for 3470. He lectures via writing on powerpoints, which he uploads after. Lecture is not mandatory but I went to them all. He's pretty funny and lectures are quality, but he sometimes flew through slides so it was hard to take notes. He did improve on this though. WebAssign sucked but 10% added to HW grade. Overall, I really liked him.
Made Stats super great :) total hotty

summary_comment: Dr. Xu is highly regarded for her exceptional teaching skills, characterized by organization, clarity, and a supportive approach. Students appreciate her engaging and inclusive classroom environment, where she encourages questions and uses real-world examples to enhance understanding. Her well-structured lectures and availability outside of class contribute to a comprehensive learning experience.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Xu is organized, kind, and takes a genuine interest in the students of this course. She goes out of her way to ask for and answer questions, and she clearly is of the "no question is a dumb question" mindset, which created a relaxed, open learning environment that everyone benefitted from.
Dr. Xu was one of the best stats professors Ive had in my 4 years at Ohio state. She conveys the material affectively and genuinely.
The course was well organized and I learned a lot. Dr. Xu's overall demeanor is very approachable, so I felt comfortable asking her questions.

Dr. Xu is an excellent instructor. She started out each class with a minireview from the previous class, and then launched into the new material, which was very helpful. If she felt that students were not understanding a topic, she rephrased it, often using real world examples to illustrate her point.

Dr. Xu's lectures always felt well planned and timed so that every class felt like we accomplished what she had intended and we never felt rushed. She showed a rare combination of the organization and fluidity of an experienced teacher with energy and enthusiasm of a newer teacher.

It has been a pleasure taking stats with Dr. Xu this semester. I came in with minimal background in stats and struggled a bit throughout the year, but Dr. Xu was always friendly and helpful when I asked questions. Additionally, Dr. Xu showed an amount of care and concern for her students which I have found rare during my time in college.

I really enjoyed Dr. Xu's course and am very happy I signed up to take it. Her lectures are well structured and pacing is very good. Dr. Xu was very helpful and made herself available to help with questions I had via email, always answering in a timely manner.

Dr. Xu taught a complex subject clearly and comprehensively. She explained the content well, was willing to elaborate or answer questions in class, and was very organized. I enjoyed the mixed style of whiteboard and R on a computer.
Dr. Xu is always wellorganized and makes good use of class time  no minute in class is wasted, which I appreciate. She explains things clearly and reiterates important points.

The instructor did a great job of breaking down the work into manageable concepts that build on one another. The class moved at a perfect pace. The amount of work and exams were appropriate. I learned a great deal in the class and appreciate the professor. She would always check in with us to make sure we understood. She was very approachable.

Really excellent professor! Whenever I had a question she always cleared it up. She really knew what she was talking about. Very organized and genuinely interested in helping students learn and always very prepared. Very positive as well.

She is a nice professor, but kind of unaware of how to deliver materials clearly. As a result, at least I am totally confused when doing assignment: how is this question related to her lecture? Her lecture is conductive, but hard to figure out what is important, what is should be mastered for exam. Having been confused for a whole semester.

Professor Xu was an average professor as her explanations were sometimes difficult to understand. She is friendly so don't be afraid to ask a question. Go to the Math Learning Center if you need homework help as it is 30% of the total grade. It is also helpful to go there before exams. Overall, the class is quite manageable.

I feel like Dr. Xu cared, however, I feel as if she could not display the material in an efficient way. Lectures were rather unclear and they did not help me in understanding the material. If you utilize the tutor room, you will be able to do well in the class, however. It will take some work though. More than what I was expecting.

Her lectures are her just reading the textbook. And in recitation you do nothing even related to the lecture. It really is funny how in the first couple weeks attendance of the lecture dropped by about 30%.

SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: The Statistical Analysis of Time Series

SEI.Subject: STAT
SEI.Class Name: The Statistical Analysis of Time Series

summary_comment: This professor is widely regarded as challenging, with lectures that are dense and difficult to follow, particularly due to an overemphasis on derivations without enough practical examples. Despite this, students appreciate the professor's care and fairness, noting that exams are curved generously. Overall, while the professor is seen as caring and fair, many students find the course structure and content presentation to be suboptimal for effective learning.

Ratings.comment: Like said below, probably the hardest course taken. TA is good, he cares and motivates students well, hope his voice is louder. Lecturer is also caring, it seems that his slides are well prepared and I hope he explained a bit more about calculation details. The first exam is tough, the second is slightly easier though.

Wasiur asked us to know both the derivatives of some formulas and the use of them. Some examples he talked on classes were involved. But he would explain our questions clearly and patiently. He is caring and curved the exams pretty fairly.

This is his first semester teaching, and you could tell. Lectures are very confusing and hard to follow; it seems like he needs to figure out how to explain material in a more easy to understand way. However, he is very caring and curved exams generously. He just made the class unnecessarily hard. Could be a great professor with more experience.

Those practice tests were "different because they were written by a different teacher." The lecture,hw, and recitation covered different material to cover more ground, yet hw is indirectly for a grade through online quizzes. "The hint actually makes the problem harder." Take another class if possible. He's learning to teach maybe. Such a bad start.

Never have I walked into a class with almost no understanding of a topic, and then left the class with even less understanding. He would spend a majority of the time deriving formulas incorrectly. What he does cannot be qualified as teaching because the students cannot learn. If you have to take this class for your major, wait to take it.

Probably the hardest course I've taken in college by a pretty wide margin. Lecture is proof heavy with little examples and recitation is completely pointless as the only thing that goes on there is one example that is completely off topic and rambling. That being said, Wasiur is fair and understanding and has curved the exams pretty fairly.

If you care about learning stats or studying for the actuary exam, do not take this course with him. Lectures don't seem to correlate to homework or exams and are extremely hard to follow. Gives you practice exams that look absolutely nothing like the actual exam he gives. Makes content that should be relatively simple seem incredibly complicated.

Prepare to spend the majority of lecture doing derivations of every formula that's used in the class. Applicable examples are few, and they're either A) Too easy, not helpful for HW or exams, or B) Extremely hard to follow, often seeming to not be relevant to what we're currently learning. Tests are EXTREMELY hard; hardest I've taken in my life.

summary_comment: This professor is consistently criticized for poor communication and an inability to relate course material to the exam. Students find his lectures overly theoretical with no practical examples, and he fails to prepare students adequately for the 70% exam component. Overall, his teaching approach is deemed ineffective and confusing, with many advising students to avoid him.

Ratings.comment: He was a bad teacher who always would say the stuff he was teaching was beyond the scope of the class, but never talked about what was in the class. He didnt communicate the material well. If you can, avoid him.

Spends the whole class explaining proofs but fails to provide actual examples that would be used on the exams, which make up 70% of the total grade. Does not encourage student participation and only further complicates problems during office hours. Also shows up very unprepared to lectures. Overall, do not recommend Nick

Lectures were spent proving theory, and never going over application problems, which were the types on exam. Provides 0 guidance as to exam content, no review, no practice problems, etc. Was not helpful and always either extremely vague or spoke on ridiculously technical levels. Does not know how to communicate materials to the average student.

summary_comment: The professor is perceived as having a clear teaching style, making the content accessible and not particularly difficult. However, several students found the lectures unhelpful and only attended for extra credit opportunities, indicating a lack of engagement with the material during classes. Despite this, the labs and exams were relatively easy, with students allowed extensive notes for the midterm and final.

Ratings.comment: Great TA. Not hard content. Did a good job explaining things in a clear cut way.

I really did not enjoy this class. At the beginning of the semester I went to every class, took notes, got the extra credit & studied for the midterm but still did poorly. The lectures are not helpful, by the middle of the semester the only reason I was still going was for the EC TopHat points. Not hard material but you have to teach yourself.

Definitely not a hard class. Nice woman but I just literally gained NOTHING from going to lecture. The only reason I would go was because of TopHat extra credit questions. Really easy labs and content for the most part. You're allowed a full page front and back for the midterm and the final.

summary_comment: The professor is highly regarded for his lenient grading, relatable teaching style, and ability to make even early morning classes enjoyable. Students find him extremely helpful, fair, and dedicated to their success, often praising his clear explanations and availability to assist.

Ratings.comment: Awesome professor! He's a PhD student, so pretty lenient on grading and homework. Go to class, he gives extra credit randomly. Exam's are a piece of cake, you get one sheet of notes. Makes the 8am class bearable!
So nice and is always willing to help. He is a PhD student so he is really relatable with students. Would take again and the class was actually enjoyable :)
Professor is very laid back and understanding.

Corey has excellent lectures and does a great job of explaining the material in a way that is relatable to everyone. He is always available and wanting to help his students. He is very fair and honest and actually does a great job of teaching and preparing his students for the homework assignments, recitation activities and exams.

summary_comment: Dr. Zhu's teaching quality varies widely according to student feedback. Some students found his lectures effective at breaking down complex concepts and appreciated the extra credit opportunities, while others struggled to follow his explanations and found the recitations unhelpful. Overall, the class appears to be somewhat easier due to the format of exams and the allowance of cheat sheets, though some found the material challenging and the grading system unfair.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Zhu is a good lecturer. He breaks down hard concepts and explains things pretty well. At least with our class the material was pretty challenging and at times im not sure if he realized that or knew which concepts were the difficult ones but he still taught the material really well. Cheat sheet + hard work gets you an A

Kind of like a easy A class. His midterms and final are similar to homework problems and sample midterm. Also, he allows students to bring cheat sheets to test. If you write all the homework problems on the cheat sheets, you can get a easy A. The class average is like A-, about 90%.

I feel like he tried, but nothing he said in that class made sense to me. The homework was graded for correctness which sucked. The quizzes weren't bad, but they're weren't many of them so they were weighted pretty heavy. The midterm and the final were awful! They were very hard and didn't seem like anything we had learned in class.

Talks very slow which kind of helps you understand the topics better. Lectures were fine, but recitations were awful. We had to use the software R and it is very confusing and no one wants to help. Thankfully, recitation didn't have much points tied to it. There were two exams and final was not cumulative. Midterm was easy, but the final was hard!

Dr. Zhu was honestly one of the worst professors I've had. His lectures are incredibly dull, and he spends half of the class reviewing what we had just gone over in the last lecture. His examples he went over in lecture were terrible. The only good thing about this class is that the midterm is super easy and the final is only slightly harder.

Dr. Zhu was an okay professor. He provided us with great extra credit opportunities. His lectures were okay but I guess it is hard to make a statistics lecture be that interesting, in my opinion. He was accessible outside of class especially during finals week. His quizzes and exams were rather fair as long as you fully understood the homework.

Dr zhu is not a very great professor. It was hard to understand him and it looked like he was very confused about what he was teaching. Recitations were pointless but you have to attain them as u get quizzes and need to submit your homework in rec. I would avoid this professor if you can. No extra credits or curves.

He put in a lot of effort in making sure that students were able to understand the material by going through examples in class and was helpful when you asked questions. The structure of the course was weird and the recitations were pointless other than to get the quiz points. He was a lot better than dr Xu and he his posted annotated notes online.
Dr. Zhu was a great professor. The class wasn't terribly easy, but it was one of the few where I could actually feel myself thinking.
Lecture is clear. He is very nice as a person. He always explains things clearly and goes though lots of examples.

I only got an A in this course because I took AP Statistics in high school. Going to his lectures is pointless - he just reads power points that he puts on Carmen and he doesn't do example problems. Quizzes are easy because they're based on "homework" problems but the second midterm was impossible. I don't think he knew the material for this course

Quizzes were easy and simple, but midterms and final were unfair and confusing. He basically just reads off slides that he posts on Carmen. Lectures were boring. Unfortunately, he is the only professor for this course. The textbook got me through this course. I only got an A bc I previously learned the material in high school and used the textbook

Absolutely horrible at grading! The second exam was curved and the average after the curve was 44%. The grading did not represent my knowledge of the subject. You will most likely get almost perfect scores on the quizzes just to fail the exams. He was a very nice person though, just not the best grader.

quiz:easy&manageable if work on the HW. sample:way too easy. real exam:not even close to the samplequizHWtextbook exercisesinclass exampleanything you can see in this course. midterm1 okay, midterm2 ridiculous&unconventional. prof doesn't seem to care much. recitation: not really helping until they changed the content of it to discuss HW.

His quiz are from homework directly, but sometimes there's no enough time. First midterm is moderate, but second one is awful and very tough. The contents covered in midterm is not exactly what he told you on schedule. He didn't prepare well for this course. Material he used is from professors in other university which not really fit the textbook.

summary_comment: Prateek is highly regarded as one of the best instructors for STAT3201, making complex material easily understandable and going above and beyond to support student success. Students strongly recommend him and express a desire for him to teach more statistics courses.

Ratings.comment: Prateek is one of the best, if not the best, instructors for STAT3201. He makes the material extremely easy to understand, and he goes out of his way to help students and help them do the very best in STAT3201. 10/10 would recommend, I wish he taught more STAT classes.

summary_comment: Claire is highly regarded as an excellent and passionate professor, known for making her courses accessible and engaging. Students appreciate her clear explanations, passion for the subject, and the practical applications of the material. The workload is consistent and manageable, with assignments that typically take less than an hour to complete, and exams that are straightforward if studied adequately.

Ratings.comment: Claire is an excellent professor, and you really will learn a lot from this course. There is a lot of weekly work, but it will not take you long to complete at all. Attendance is for points, but you can skip twice without penalty. Midterm and Final are super straight forward and don't require much studying. Definitely take this course!!

Greatest professor at OSU. If you are debating taking HDFS2200, take it. Easiest A you will ever receive. She assigns a lot on a weekly basis but they take less than an hour to complete (total) once you get in the groove. I would rather go to University of Michigan than not take Claire's class. If you want a bad life, don't take this class.
Loved this class, good into to HDFS

Claire is a super nice and passionate teacher when it comes to HDFS. As long as you talk in class with your discussion group and do the few assignments a week that literally take less the 20 minutes, you'll get a good grade. Midterm and Final were super easy as well if you prepare at least a little for them.

Claire is clearly passionate about what she teaches. Lectures are a "flipped classroom," so come to class with all of your work already completed. Weekly quizzes, discussion posts, and readings/activities.

You definitely need the book, and will read alot. Exams were very easy if you studied. Lots of assignments but they are all pretty easy. Great teacher, brings videos,games, and other people into lectures. Loved this teacher and this class. She truly cares about all ththe students and talks about her kids a lot. Wonderful women. Loved this class

I took the in class version and I am so happy I did. Each week is set up the exact same so no surprises. There are online quizzes, an assignment, and a reflection due every week. Everything is clearly explained and she is a hilarious teacher. You can tell she is passionate about her class and I have learned alot to apply to my everyday life.

Claire was one of my favorite professors at OSU. If you take the class in person, all you have to do is show up and participate in your small group. Super easy class and is actually helpful in real-life situations.

Took this class online and heard the in person was so0 much easier. I ended up with over a 100% in the class but there are a lot of assignments. You're placed in a group and have to depend on your group members to do their work for you to be able to do yours. This class was organized poorly but it was the first semester so it's understandable.

summary_comment: Dr. Auddy is an excellent professor known for his dedication and support, consistently helping students both inside and outside of class. While the course material can be challenging, students appreciate his fairness and the difficulty level of exams and homeworks. With consistent effort, success in the class is attainable.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Auddy is a good professor who cares about his students, and is always willing to help and answer questions inside and outside of class. I didn't enjoy the class material itself but I was very happy Dr. Auddy was the one teaching it to me. Exams and homeworks were difficult but fair. If you stay on top of things, you will do well in this class.

summary_comment: Professor Hans is highly regarded for his understanding and caring nature, though his lectures can be dry at times. Students find his classes well-organized and fair, with clear expectations and ample opportunities for practice through homework and exams. While some find the lectures less engaging, many appreciate his willingness to help and his fairness in grading.

Ratings.comment: Very nice and understanding Professor.

Professor Hans is fantastic. The exams can be a bit tricky but this class is definitely doable if you put in the effort. Favorite OSU stats professor so far. If you ever need anything he is very caring/flexible if you email.

pretty good professor. really nice guy, really cares about his students and wants them to learn. hes very fair and is always willing to help. the class is laid out the same for each week so theres no guessing as to whats due this week? i wish the lectures were live because its hard to pay attention. exams were pretty hard, you need to study.

The course is fully online, but Dr. Hans and Katherine made the course worth taking. The class is extremelly well organized: we had a to-do list for every week, and the lecture videos are fairly concise and informative. We also got a lot of practice from weekly homeworks, so we know what to expect in the exams (exams can be somehow challenging).

Dr. Hans is an excellent professor who goes through the material in depth and makes sure students understands everything clearly. Although he occasionally engages with the students, the class itself is boring.

Very average guy. He was pretty generous on exams but overall he was a really dry lecturer and not very helpful in office hours. Going to his lectures was kind of a waste of time - I learned the content for the class through the textbook.

Take this teacher! He is clear, helpful, and very nice/approachable.  I bombed one of the midterms but after talking to him about it, he really helped me out.  Go to class and do the homework and you should pretty much be set for the tests.

Excellent professor. Lectures were unfortunately not the most interesting, but the tests were very fair, actually a bit easier than the homeworks, and the homeworks were great preparation for the tests. Prof Hans was VERY easy to approach with questions, and extremely helpful. Highly recommended!

How all stats/math professors should be.  Knowledgable, fair, approchable, helpful.  Fair tests.  No quizzes.  Drops the 2 lowest homeworks. Final 35% of your grade.  Class isn't the simplest but if you in the necessary time you'll be fine.
No Comments
The recommended exercises are important for the exams.  Very nice and approachable. Very helpful in office hours.

summary_comment: Professor Rodgers is widely regarded as an ineffective lecturer, with students finding his classes boring and difficult to follow due to rapid slide presentations and unclear verbal communication. His teaching style is described as slow and unengaging, with many students recommending alternative resources such as online lectures by other instructors. Students also noted his reluctance to move forward without immediate responses to his questions, which further contributed to the challenging nature of the class.

Ratings.comment: All of his slides are itemized and he FLIES by problems. I ended up taking pictures on my phone and copying it down later. The most painful class I have taken. Dude is so lucky stats is a semi-self explanatory class because NO ONE would have passed if it was genuinely hard. He also sits and waits for someone to answer his questions no matter what

The worst TA I've ever met. Slow and rough reply for email. Most strict, stubborn, rigid, I would say if you can take stat in-person, don't choose online or you'll regret when you meet this guy. Bad at all.
Boring lectures, mumbles pretty often, but he's a good guy
Boring
I'm sure Keith is a nice guy but he is just a terrible lecturer. Save your time and watch Deborah's lectures online and even that probably won't help so stick to teaching yourself through Youtube.
Not a good lecturer, hard to understand and not good at speaking to a crowd. Just use Dr. Rumsey's online lecturers which are shorter and more clear. The class was pretty easy as well.

Even though it's a standardized course, he managed to be the most boring lecturer I've ever had. Half the time, we didn't even get through all the material on the weekly quiz. Ended up not going and watching Rumsey's online podcasts, which saved a lot of time. Definitely recommend doing her online class for this instead of Rodgers.
